1122202415837716480.text: Everyone wants information asymmetry - more insight into others, and more control over what we reveal of ourselves.

1122207591935778816.text: While users are preoccupied with relative advantage, checking out others and accumulating social capital, the mediating platform accrues an asymmetrical advantage like a bank profiting off deposits.

1122215775765295104.text: Time will tell if this is an acceptable tradeoff. You pledge your data and receive certain benefits in return - the new technofeudal social contract. It seems to mostly be working and the people who don't like it are cranks isolating themselves from the main currents of exchange.

People didn't know how much data we collected... so why begin a conversation that would confuse and concern everyone?"

1121976702165323776.text: They quickly demonstrated how profitable "behavioral surplus" could be. Google would secure more behavioral data than it needed to serve its users, and use that game-changing, zero-cost asset not for service improvements, but to sell predictions to third parties.

1121976701200637952.text: Google's initial revenues came from licensing deals for their technology and sponsored ads. But after the Dot Com bust, pressure to show greater profits mounted. The company started mining behavioral data to more precisely target ads.

1067564630766055425.text: This book mostly raises questions it can't answer, but its contribution is an attempt to focus on the right questions, because "In a world deluged by irrelevant information, clarity is power."

1067563740369842176.text: Meditation is a tool for observing the mind directly. A useful tool in a world where feelings and perceptions are easily manipulated.

1067563739048636417.text: “People afraid of losing their truth tend to be more violent than people who are used to looking at the world from several different viewpoints. Questions you cannot answer are usually far better for you than answers you cannot question.”

1067563738201382912.text: How to avoid brainwashing: 1. If you want reliable information, pay good money for it. 2. If some issue seems exceptionally important to you, make the effort to read the relevant scientific literature (original sources)

1067563736972455936.text: “The power of human cooperation depends on a delicate balance between truth and fiction. If you stick to unalloyed reality, few people will follow you.” False stories have an advantage, since if people believe something with no evidence, they are more likely to be loyal followers

1067563736079073281.text: Not only are crowds fallible, but so are leaders. “If you cannot afford to waste time, you will never find the truth. Worse still, great power inevitably distorts the truth. Power is all about changing reality rather than seeing it for what it is.”

1067563734778884102.text: Humans have physical and cognitive capabilities. In the industrial revolution, machines replaced physical labor, but created new cognitive labor jobs. When AI replaces those, we don’t know know of any third field of activity where humans will have an edge.

1067563733818388481.text: "It is harder to struggle against irrelevance than against exploitation." Mass industrial society relied on the ordinary laborer in a way that resulted in mass economic and political empowerment.

1067563732803321856.text: "If data becomes concentrated in too few hands, humankind will split into different species.” Once creativity and intelligence can be augmented, a gap may emerge between rich and poor that becomes increasingly impossible to close.

1067563731356311552.text: To prevent the concentration of all wealth and power into the hands of a small elite, the key is to regulate the ownership of data. The primary means of production has changed from land, to factories, to data in the information era.

1067563730290917376.text: In the 20th century democracies outperformed dictatorships because they were better at data processing. However, soon AI might swing the pendulum in the opposite direction. AI makes it possible to centrally process enormous amounts of information.

1067563729468841985.text: We are approaching a point where we can shape humans themselves, not just the external world. “We will learn how to design brains, extend lives, and kill thoughts at our discretion. Nobody knows what the consequences will be."

1067563728579682304.text: Democracy relies upon trusting human feelings. But if anyone "gains the technological ability to hack and manipulate the human heart, democratic politics will mutate into an emotional puppet show."

1067563727430414336.text: Liberalism is in crisis, and it remains to be seen whether it will reinvent itself again. Economic growth as a solution to discontent accelerates the challenges posed by ecological devastation and technological disruption.

1040682030445412353.text: This is not the past year anymore, but I'm just going to keep going since people have reminded me of other books, and there's value to having it all in one place:

1040492110879715328.text: Dune - In the dark ages of the future, there is environmental devastation, medieval gender roles, and backstabbing among the aristocrats. We traded AI overlords for feudalism and jihad going to war over nootropics in space?

1040485348143316993.text: Some Foundation novels by Asimov - With the ultimate model for data analysis, we can predict and control society to build a powerful empire. A dream at the dawn of cybernetics.

1040480417026007040.text: Accelerando by Charles Stross - Welcome to the Singularity, AIs and DAOs will consume everything, and the only way to survive is to radically transform yourself.

1040477324007792640.text: Lilith's Brood by Octavia Butler - Perhaps high intelligence combined with violent, hierarchical tendencies is a fatal flaw in a species. How much genetic engineering to change human nature would you put up with?

1040477191878762496.text: Ancillary Justice by @ann_leckie - Gender and racial hierarchies will become obsolete, but in the hierarchy of civilization, luxury always comes at someone else's expense.

1040474363365974017.text: The Three-Body Problem trilogy by Liu Cixin - If the vast universe is a Nietzchean struggle for survival, at what scale do human values matter? Deeply Chinese pragmatic nihilism. Too much prosperity leads to weakness and arrogance, which is fatal.

1040473683578388480.text: Daemon & Freedom by @itsDanielSuarez - What is freedom if humans and societies are just systems with incentive structures that can be gamed? How powerful could DAOs become...?

968184456648392705.text: I'm one of the women from the Palo Alto meetup who's quoted, but what I said on the difficulty of going from a non-technical background to becoming a developer is taken out of context, and my emphasis on how easy it is to get involved, compared to other fields, is not included.

968187722983555072.text: I expected an article on women in cryptocurrency to highlight many of the much more prominent women in the space, rather than a meetup which was a casual post-conference gathering. That doesn't seem very well-researched or representative.

968271681599938560.text: Feel free to DM me if you're a woman or non-CS newbie learning how to do blockchain development and want tips, encouragement, or just a sympathetic ear. You're not alone, and there's a lot to discover on the other side of that learning curve!

968267171913613312.text: So realistically, it's psychologically tough for an outsider to enter tech/blockchain tech, but well worth it if you push through, and the culture will only change as more get involved. I hope a more diverse set of people shape this future.

968261959480000512.text: And the potential for impact is huge. Code replicates infinitely, can be published and run by anyone, anywhere, and reshapes information flows which in turn reshapes the possibility space of society. It's an exciting and terrifying frontier.

968257509780684800.text: For a developer, cryptocurrency projects are even more accessible than the rest of tech because most of the code is open source, but unlike most open source projects, if you just jump in and start doing things you'll also most likely find a way to be compensated.

968253768675483652.text: The barriers to entry for tech are very low compared to any other professional field. Male or female, you can make it without a CS degree, with no initial capital costs other than a computer, and all the material you need to learn and start practicing is freely available online.

968250859954974720.text: A fascination with the underlying tech and a focus on the importance made me determined to stay, and keep diving deeper. And in the bigger picture, few eras of history have put as much knowledge and opportunity at our fingertips as the computing era.

968247732279296000.text: My inner critic was harsh, and the world gave it plenty of material to feed on. Front-end and UI work, where I started out and which lots of women do, was not as valued. Random trolls would roll through insisting women can't code and I'd fume for days.

968247730739933184.text: As an enthusiastic newbie starting out on my coding journey, I underestimated how hard these things would be for me to deal with. A year or two in, I started to understand why women leave technical roles. It's a men's cultural milieu, so it feels like swimming upstream.

968241140011905024.text: I got into cryptocurrency development as I learned programming, and experienced the challenges of a newcomer to a field where they're not well represented: questioning my belonging, not having role models, lacking confidence to speak up, deflecting stereotypes.

968238842833588224.text: To set the record straight, in this article I'm talking about the challenges of imposter syndrome faced by a woman from a non-CS background entering tech, and my entry point of blockchain tech. The positive side I tried to convey did not get covered here.https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/25/business/cryptocurrency-women-blockchain-bros.html …
